docs.snippet: The new recommendations from the World Health Organization could go a long way toward halting an epidemic, but implementation would cost billions of dollars not yet committed.
docs.lead_paragraph: The new recommendations from the World Health Organization could go a long way toward halting an epidemic, but implementation would cost billions of dollars not yet committed.
docs.abstract: World Health Organization issues significant updates to its current  recommendations for managing HIV, proposing to put patients across globe on antiretroviral therapy of three drugs immediately after diagnosis; new treatment is standard in United States and much of developed world but following new guidelines globally could increase population of HIV-positive patients on antiretroviral drugs by 9 million and cost untold billions of dollars, with no sure source of funding.

headline.main: Millions More Need H.I.V. Treatment, W.H.O. Says
headline.print_headline: World Health Group Proposes Extending H.I.V. Therapy’s Reach

docs.snippet: The rush of refugees into Europe has stirred new urgency among Western leaders to address the war in Syria and push harder for an end to it.
docs.lead_paragraph: The rush of refugees into Europe has stirred new urgency among Western leaders to address the war in Syria and push harder for an end to it.
docs.abstract: Influx of Syrian refugees into Europe, coupled with fear Islamic State militants may cross Continent’s porous borders, spurs world leaders to request meeting with Antonio Guterres, United Nations high commissioner for refugees; Guterres has been pleading Syrian refugee cause to international community since 2011 but is only now getting response; four million refugees have arrived in Europe from Syria since 2011, and Guterres expresses opinion that sudden attention to crisis is simply because it is now impacting wealthy nations.

headline.main: Refugee Crisis in Europe Prompts Western Engagement in Syria
headline.print_headline: Influx Puts Refugee Crisis on West’s Agenda

docs.snippet: Dr. Curvin, a co-founder of the Newark chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, helped make Kenneth A. Gibson the first black mayor of a major Northeast city.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Curvin, a co-founder of the Newark chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, helped make Kenneth A. Gibson the first black mayor of a major Northeast city.
docs.abstract: Robert Curvin, a fiercely loyal advocate for Newark who co-founded Newark chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality and served on editorial board of The New York Times for nearly 6 years, dies at age 81.

headline.main: Robert Curvin, Scholar Who Fought Bias and Poverty in Newark, Dies at 81

docs.snippet: Ben Brantley and Anthony Tommasini weigh in on the debate set off by the Metropolitan Opera’s decision to forgo darkening makeup in its latest production.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Brantley and Anthony Tommasini weigh in on the debate set off by the Metropolitan Opera’s decision to forgo darkening makeup in its latest production.
docs.abstract: New York Times critics Ben Brantley and Anthony Tommasini debate Metropolitan Opera's decision to forego blackface makeup in production of Otello and general issue of depicting race in theater.

headline.print_headline: Scrubbing Race,  but a Debate Simmers

byline.original: By BEN BRANTLEY and ANTHONY TOMMASINI

docs.snippet: The group was aiming to reach Germany and had come from the large, long-established Ain al Hilwe Palestinian refugee camp.
docs.lead_paragraph: The group was aiming to reach Germany and had come from the large, long-established Ain al Hilwe Palestinian refugee camp.
docs.abstract: Forty Palestinians from Lebanon's Ain al Hilwe Palestinian refugee camp seeking to reach Germany by boat are arrested in Lebanese port of Tripoli, where access without security clearance or ferry ticket is prohibited.

headline.main: Lebanon: 40 Palestinians Are Arrested as They Seek to Join Migrant Wave
headline.print_headline: Middle East; Lebanon: 40 Palestinians Are Arrested as They Seek to Join Migrant Wave

docs.snippet: Clashes between rival Christian and Muslim militias made it too dangerous to help the wounded and recover bodies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Clashes between rival Christian and Muslim militias made it too dangerous to help the wounded and recover bodies.
docs.abstract: Aid officials say increasingly dangerous level of violence between Muslim and Christian sects in Bangui, Central African Republic, is preventing aid groups from accessing and operating in capital, where clashes have killed at least 42 people.

headline.main: Central African Republic: Aid Groups Seek Better Access to Strife-Torn Capital
headline.print_headline: Africa; Central African Republic: Aid Groups Seek Better Access to Strife-Torn Capital

docs.snippet: The proposed agreement, which would be a legacy achievement for President Obama, has had trade ministers deadlocked over pharmaceutical drug protections, auto exports and other matters.
docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed agreement, which would be a legacy achievement for President Obama, has had trade ministers deadlocked over pharmaceutical drug protections, auto exports and other matters.
docs.abstract: Officials from United States and 11 Pacific nations resume trade deal negotiations; significant differences between participants persist, and prospects have also been harmed by slew of criticism from American presidential candidates.

headline.main: Pacific Trade Deal Talks Resume, Under Fire From U.S. Presidential Hopefuls
headline.print_headline: Pacific Trade Deal Talks Resume, Under Fire From U.S. Presidential Hopefuls
